awd_titl_txt: The evolutionary origins of multicellularity and development in experimental populations of digital organisms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates fundamental questions about how evolution produces shifts in what it means to be an individual organism and how those shifts affect subsequent evolution. What is an individual organism varies greatly. With bacteria, an individual consists of a single cell, while in mammals individuals might have trillions of cells, all coordinating different roles (blood, skin, and so forth) Some species, such as the honey bee, form highly coordinated colonies (with queens, foragers, guards, and so forth) that behave like an individual organism. The evolution of previously distinct entities (cells or insects) into new types of unified individuals (bodies or colonies) are challenging to study because  evolution occurs over long time scales. Instead, the researchers will use computer simulations in which they will manipulate environmental conditions to see how they promote or constrain the evolution of complex individuals. The researchers will also develop web-based software to let others easily explore these evolutionary transitions, with a goal of simplifying experimentation by fellow researchers, facilitating student learning, and promoting citizen science.
 
This project will be divided into three conceptual stages: (1) Formation: Under what selective conditions do formerly solitary organisms unite to form a higher-level individual unit? (2) Differentiation: Once higher-level units have been formed, how do the preexisting traits of the lower-level individuals (such as phenotypic plasticity or environmental interactions) influence the evolution of division-of-labor strategies? (3) Complexification: How do different types of division-of-labor mechanisms facilitate the evolution of new, more complex features (such as developmental patterns or tightly-coordinated task performance)? The researchers will use an experimental-evolution approach with digital study organisms that operate in a 2D virtual world. Digital evolution systems allow the researchers to observe all genomes in a population, track all interactions, and record perfect phylogenies. Each digital cell has a fully-functional genetic program, theoretically capable of performing any algorithmic processes. Evolution in these systems frequently produce unexpected survival strategies with complex environmental and inter-cellular interactions, far beyond a traditional simulation. Probing the conditions that produce major transitions in an open-ended and transparent system will contribute to a deeper understanding of our natural origins, generate numerous hypotheses that can be tested concisely in laboratory experiments, and promote ideas for how computational algorithms can be produced that coordinate at a scale comparable to biological systems.

por.por_cntn:
The evolution of biological complexity has long fascinated biologists and is the source of amazement (and skepticism) about the evolutionary process. Major evolutionary transitions are at the heart of the most profound complexity advances. They redefine what it means to be an "individual" and upgrade evolution's toolkit, opening new possibilities for traits and behaviors. These major transitions typically occur when formerly distinct individuals unite to form a higher-level unit that functions as a single entity. If the original individuals were unrelated, such a transition is called "egalitarian", such as the formation of eucaryotic cells from bacteria and mitochondria.  Here we focused on "fraternal" transitions where the original individuals were all related. Examples include single cells adhering together to form multicellular organisms or solitary insects uniting to form colonies. The fossil record lacks the detail needed to reconstruct the conditions that produced such major transitions in the natural world, while the slow pace of evolution makes it challenging to reproduce such events in laboratory settings.

For this project, we developed computational systems with open-ended evolutionary dynamics where major transitions can occur on time scales that are tractable for experimentation. We used these systems to systematically study fundamental questions about the processes responsible for major transitions, the ordering of events, and the types of multicellular organisms that are produced.

The data collection and analysis tools that we built to facilitate this project include:
* The MODES Toolbox - a set of metrics to measure the "open-endedness" of evolving digital systems. More open-ended systems produce more complex and novel organisms; major evolutionary transitions are a key hallmark of such systems.
* Tools to quantify the tape of life.  Specifically, we study evolutionary lineages (ancestors back through time) to understand how evolution progressed.
* Data standards for Artificial Life Software.  These standards strengthen the research community by facilitating the sharing of analysis tools.

We also developed a set of software tools for building artificial life systems capable of undergoing major evolutionary transitions.
* CONDIUT is a library for "best effort" distributed computing.  Rather than always making sure inter-processes messages are delivered correctly, it allows occasional messages to be lost in exchange for a substantial speed-up.  Taking advantage of such lossy environments (which are standard in nature), allows us to build large-scale artificial life software systems.
* Hstrat (or "Hereditary Stratigraphy") is a set of algorithms that allow us to track relationships among digital organisms over time, and track a "Tree of life" even when we lose some data.
* SignalGP is a type of virtual hardware where organisms can respond to environmental signals and send out signals of their own.  We demonstrated that SignalGP is more evolvable than common techniques at evolving solutions to some challenging problems.
* DISTINY uses the above components to evolve large populations of cells, each controlled by SignalGP virtual hardware.  Given sufficiently large populations, we can observe the de novo evolution of multiple levels of transitions in individuality.  Populations must be distributed over many CPUs, but CONDIUT made this possible, along with Hstrat to enable data collection.

We contributed many important results.  These include:
* Phenotypic plasticity, the ability for organisms to change their traits or behaviors based in their environment, is also important for cells in a multicellular organism to engage in division of labor.  We demonstrated how this capacity can stabilize organisms in the face of fluctuating environments.
* We demonstrated that genomes in multicellular organisms will evolve to become more robust to harmful mutations in individual cells if one "bad" cell can bring down the whole group.
* Sometimes cells have to kill themselves in order to improve the fitness of a multicellular organism (either because they need to perform a dangerous task or because something else has gone wrong in them).  We have shown that this "programmed cell death" can evolve not only in multicellular organisms, but even in unicellular organisms due solely to kin selection
* Finally, we performed many experiments with the DISTINY system and showed the frequent evolution of multicellular organisms under a variety of conditions, and even more than one level of transition to more complex forms.  These digital multicells have proven to have a wide variety of survival strategies, and even include having outer skins, supporting their offspring, and engaging in high-level forms of cooperation and resource sharing.  This system has proven to be surprisingly powerful and will be the basis of many future studies.

Important in this work is that we have ensured that our tools, software, and data are freely available, and in many cases have built web applications for others to try out the software online.
